name: Sampangan
notes: No visible remains. Reported by Bernet Kempers

name: Fort Canning 1984
notes: When the British arrived in Singapore in 1819, the hill was known as the Forbidden Hill by the local population because according to legend the palace of their ancestors once stood there. Excavations have been performed there since 1984, starting with several test pits around the Keramat Iskandar Shah.

name: Pulau Saigon 1990
notes: Surface finds were collected in late 1989 and early 1990 from a site on the opposite bank and further up the Singapore River from Fort Canning. No systematic excavation was possible. Most of the finds dated to the colonial period, but a small number of 14th century sherds are intriguing evidence of the extent of settlement at that period.

name: Istana Kampung Glam 2000
notes: The grounds of the palace of the Sultan of Singapore did not yield 14th century artefacts, but rather a rich assortment of artefacts from the 1790s and onwards.

name: Colombo Court 2000
notes:
July-August 2000
Excavations took place as the land was being prepared for construction of the new Supreme Court Building in 2000. The site yielded many 14th century artifacts and is notable for also including Chinese and Vietnamese ceramics from the 1500s, suggesting that a settlement along the Singapore river continued after the court had moved to Melaka.

name: The Singapore Cricket Club
notes:
April 16 to May 2, 2003
The Padang turned out to be rich in 14th century remains. One important find was a layer of white sand underlying the 14th-century stratum, which confirmed an ancient Malay description of ancient Singapore when it was first inhabited. The main activity at the site seems to have been the working of metal, including recycling Chinese copper coins.

name: St. Andrews Cathedral
notes:
September 16, 2003 to April 10, 2004
More than 300,000 artifacts were excavated in this important campaign, held in advance of construction of underground facilities on the grounds of the St Andrew's Cathedral. Several 14th-century Chinese jars were discovered in intact condition, indicating that they had been intentionally buried. Important artifact types from the site which are rare or non-existent at other Temasek-period sites include a stone peg (perhaps a touchstone for assaying gold), carnelian beads, a Sri Lankan coin, an Indian glass bangle similar to one found on Fort Canning, a Yuan dynasty 10-cash coin, a gun flint perhaps used by one of the sepoys in the East India Company in the early 19th century, a 19th-century Thai coin (perhaps brought by Chulalongkorn on the occasion of his famous visit), two sherds of 17th-century Chinese ceramics, a piece of gold wire, a significant amount of Ming dynasty porcelain, and some Vietnamese porcelain.

Read the Site Report

name: Ft. Canning Spice Garden
notes:
April 7 to May 3, 2010
This excavation, carried out ahead of construction works on Fort Canning, allowed researchers to identify the site as a footpath leading up to the hill. Artifacts recovered were often broken, and may have been rubbish dumped on the downhill side of the footpath. The finds reinforce the hypothesis that Fort Canning was largely abandoned after 1396, whereas sites closer to the Singapore River were occupied for longer.

Read the Site Report

name: Ft Canning Rescue Dig
notes:
September 2 to November 4, 2018
This rescue excavation was carried out in areas to be affected by renovation works in preparation for Singapore's Bicentennial year. Artifact types (earthenware, stoneware, some porcelains) were consistent with other Ft Canning excavations, and did include Sawankhalok and Sukhothai pieces.

name:
Grogol Village: Majapahit Settlement
in Trowulan
notes: many ceramic sherds, pottery, pebbles, and the remains of building structures show the  characteristics of former Majapahit settlement areas.
citations: Eriawati, Y., & Nugroho, D. (2023, June). Grogol Village: Majapahit Settlement in Trowulan. In 3rd International Conference on Linguistics and Cultural (ICLC 2022) (pp. 495-505). Atlantis Press.

name: Trowulan - Former Capital City of Majapahit Kingdom
type: site of finds of moveable remains (inscription, sculpture)
notes: The Trowulan site is the only city site of the Hindu-Budha classical age in Indonesia that can still be found. The site covers an area of 11 km x 9 km, which includes the Districts of Trowulan and Sooko within the Regency of Mojokerto and the Districts of Mojoagung and Mojowarno under the Jombang Regency.Thousands of artifacts from the Trowulan Site have been discovered and preserved.  Most of these artifacts discovered by experts and those found by the local community are maintained at the Majapahit Information Centre or known as Pusat Informasi Majapahit (PIM)
citations: https://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/5466/  and Wahyudi, D. Y., & Malasari, N. N. The (Lost) Majapahit Heritage: Brick Industry versus Trowulan Cultural Heritage1.

name: Sanggrahan temple
locationNotes: also known as Cungkup Temple, is situated in Sanggrahan Village, Tulungagung Regency, East Java
notes: Historians believe that Sanggrahan Temple was constructed as a resting place for an ash transporting group. The group transported the ashes of Gayatri, a royal Buddhist priestess from the Majapahit period. It is estimated that Sanggrahan Temple was built around 1359-1389 AD, during the reign of King Hayam Wuruk in the Majapahit era. Sanggrahan Temple has been designated as a Cultural Heritage site with the Decree of Tulungagung Regent, issued in 2019 under Number 188.45/96/013/2019
citations: Bioresita, F., Hidayat, H., Kurniawan, J. R., Purnomo, S., & Grussenmeyer, P. (2023, December). 3D Modelling of Sanggrahan Temple Using UAV Imagery and Terrestrial Photogrammetry Method. In IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science (Vol. 1276, No. 1, p. 012043). IOP Publishing.

name: Bontosikuyu Shipwreck Site
locationNotes: exact location is kept private to protect the site
notes: Based on the radiocarbon dating results obtained from the bamboo, and the presence of Chinese ceramics and coins on the site, it is hypothesised that the Bontosikuyu shipwreck was a trading vessel that sailed from China, which sank off Selayar Island during the late 13th to early 14th century. The large quantity of Chinese ceramics found at the site indicate that they were the primary cargo on board the vessel. Celadon wares.
citations: Adhityatama, S., Anderson, R., Abbas, A., King, C. M., Ng, J. C. M., & Orillaneda, B. (2024). A Preliminary Report on the Late 13th-to Early 14th-Century Bontosikuyu Shipwreck Site, Selayar Island, South Sulawesi, Indonesia: A Case Study for Regional Capacity Building and Research. International Journal of Nautical Archaeology, 1-16.

name: Museum Majapahit Trowulan
type: site of finds of moveable remains (inscription, sculpture)

name: Phanom Surin wreck
notes: carried aromatic wood, ivory tusk, deer antlers, Chinese stoneware, Gulf turquoise glazed ware, and Gulf torpedo jars (one with an inscribed personal name). Recent analyses of the bitumen lining in the Phanom Surin torpedo jars (Connan et al. 2020) demonstrate two distinct Iranian bitumen sources and two types of torpedo jars. The Phanom Surin vessel was built in a sewn-plank Arab–Persian Gulf tradition (Guy 2017)
citations:
Horton M, Boivin N, Crowther A. 2020. Eastern Africa and the early Indian Ocean: understanding mobility in a globalising world. J. Egypt. Hist. 13:1/2380–408

Guy J. 2017. The Phanom Surin shipwreck, a Pahlavi inscription, and their significance for the early history of lower central Thailand. J. Siam Soc. 105:179–96[Google Scholar]
